user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_get_device_property:
```c
int metal_linux_get_device_property(struct metal_device *device,
				    const char *property_name,
				    void *output, int len)
{
	int fd = 0;
	int status = 0;
	const int flags = O_RDONLY;
	const int mode = S_IRUSR | S_IRGRP | S_IROTH;
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	char path[PATH_MAX];

	snprintf(path, sizeof(path), "%s/of_node/%s",
			 ldev->sdev->path, property_name);
	fd = open(path, flags, mode);
	if (fd < 0)
		return -errno;
	if (read(fd, output, len) < 0) {
		status = -errno;
		close(fd);
		return status;
	}

	status = close(fd);
	return status < 0 ? -errno : 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_get_device_property:
static struct linux_device *to_linux_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	return metal_container_of(device, struct linux_device, device);
}
...
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No unreachable code was found in the provided function or the related helper. Rationale:
- There are no statements following unconditional returns (each return ends the function). Every conditional (fd < 0, read(...) < 0) has both reachable true and false paths handled by code that either returns or proceeds to close and then return.
- There are no infinite loops, no gotos, no compile-time-constant conditionals that would make subsequent code impossible to reach.
- The helper to_linux_device simply returns a container_of result and is reachable from the caller.
- All statements (snprintf, open, read, close, final return) are on possible execution paths depending on runtime results from open/read/close; none are statically unreachable.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 (unreachable code). If you want checks for related issues (e.g., error-handling correctness, use of errno, or potential snprintf truncation), indicate that and I will list fragments for those investigations.
